Yes, there were allegations of human rights abuses committed by British soldiers during Operation Telic in Iraq. Some of the most serious allegations related to the mistreatment of Iraqi detainees, particularly at the Abu Ghraib prison, which was operated by US forces but where British soldiers were also present.

There were also several high-profile cases involving alleged abuses by British soldiers, including the death of hotel worker Baha Mousa, who died in British custody in 2003, and the killing of Iraqi teenager Ahmed Jabbar Kareem Ali by a British soldier in 2003.

In response to these allegations, the British Army conducted several investigations and trials of its soldiers, resulting in some convictions and disciplinary action. However, many critics argued that the investigations were inadequate and that the military justice system was not sufficiently independent or effective in dealing with human rights abuses.

As a result of the allegations, the British Army faced severe criticism at home and abroad for its conduct in Iraq, and the government established several inquiries and reviews to investigate the matter and improve accountability and oversight.
